TopicTitle: Would you buy a DLC (or a whole new game) for KSP that was for realism?

Articles.Content:
Hello! I want to start out that if this is the wrong place to post this i'm sorry, i'm new here (not really, i barely ever use the forum!). But anyway, would you buy a Expansion Pack for KSP that was exactly like Realism Overhaul but not buggy and insanely laggy? Im guessing the issue with this right now is the Unity engine. But imagine what KSP would be like in Untiy 5! So many possibilities! So, imagine a DLC for KSP that would make it Realistic and make the game run using Unity 5... Clearly this would be a gift for the very long time players or the science fanatics, not something for beginners! But still, they are planning for Multiplayer DLC right now so i doubt having and expansion at all would be much of an issue! Tell me what you think!

EDIT: Again, Amazed on how close the poll is! But what i meant on 'Realism' i meant like, having Real Planet Scale and our real solar system, Rocket Engine Thrust, Aero dynamics, and realistic progression. Not just like... Heres a Saturn 5 rocket, now take it apart and put it back together, All i meant was have real scale and realistic mods... But not CRAZY realistic like RO is right now, and the lag just adds to it D: !!

Like how they said on the wiki: Squad is committed to add multiplayer to the finished game after the success of the user created mod KMP, or Kerbal MultiPlayer. Squad says Ã¢â‚¬Å“Multiplayer is something we had planned to do after it was all said and done, but itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s time for us to start looking at it nowÃ¢â‚¬Â.[22] With 0.24 Squad specifically states that they working on the first steps to add multiplayer after career is finished.

Meaning this would be an OPTIONAL Expansion Pack for the game for players who like science and realistic space.

Imagine these in the stock game, running at 40-180 FPS...

Yes, I'd buy something like that. That doesn't necessarily mean I think KSP should turn INTO realism overhaul, just that I would definitely buy a game or a different game mode that emphasized it.

If a competitor or collaborator came along that did a professional-quality RO/RSS I would pay AAA prices for it, hands-down. RO/RSS is literally the best thing that ever happened to KSP.
I would buy something like Orbiter as graphics and physics (I know, I like more Orbiter's graphic rather than Kerbal's. It's just an opinion) and the building and control of KSP.
Not against dlc at all but in this case the idea of almost forcing realism onto players who dont want it is bad. Yes DLC paid or not is in theory optional but almost kinda tries to force itself

I dunno how much money that would be worth over the base game, but I think that'd be the right way to do it.

Once KSP reaches a stable point? Maybe.

I would probably buy it, or I would at least be likely to.

I dont have anything against paid DLCs as a concept (though not every DLC is created equal), however, I don't think that DLC really fits the spirit of KSP, nor does a paid "realism pack", IMHO. It would appear that realism *is* a core tenet of KSP, but a "kerbal" realism, if you like, "realism-lite". I can tailor other aspects of realsim as I like through mods, a DLC would force a certain degree of realism that may or may not fit in with what I want from KSP.

I might buy it, but I would be disappointed that it existed, hence I abstain from voting.

For me the only way I would purchase such a DLC is if it had everything needed to simulate the solar system.

#1 Humans (With correct sizes which includes the pods) Instead of tiny Kerbals.

#2 Complete Solar System and moons in high detail (Such a DLC have higher system requirements than stock)

#3 Correct fuels and realistic tank mass.
I like KSP so much that it's hard to imagine a DLC that I wouldn't buy (as long as it's not totally silly/ridiculously priced). A realism one would be a no-brainer.

No. Balance between difficulty and fun factor in KSP is almost ideal for me. And if it shifts too much, i can always tweak it with a mod or two. I see no reason for SQUAD to shift resources from the core game, to something that can be easily maintained with a mod.
